'''''Stolen''''' is a [[stealth-based game]] developed by [[United Kingdom|British]] video game company Blue 52 and published in [[2005 in video gaming|2005]] by Hip Games for [[PlayStation 2]], [[Xbox]] and [[Microsoft Windows]].
== Story ==
The player assumes the role of Anya Romanov, an [[acrobatics|acrobatic]], high-tech professional [[Theft|thief]] living in the futuristic dark metropolis Forge City. Her initial mission is to infiltrate a high-security museum and steal items therein. She is assisted by the computer expert Louie Palmer, who communicates with her through an [[earpiece]]. Later on however Anya is framed for murder she didn't commit and finds out about a sinister [[conspiracy fiction|conspiracy]] involving a ruthless [[political corruption|corrupt politician]] Richard Killian and her own deadly [[female ninja]] rival known only as Breeze.
== Gameplay ==
Anya has several hi-tech [[gadget]]s to assist her, including [[Night vision device|night vision goggles]] and a multi-use [[Tranquilliser gun|dart gun]]. Notably, Anya has no lethal arms at her disposal: because of her personal moral code the player cannot kill any of the guards and other enemies she encounters, and can only knock them [[unconsciousness|unconscious]] for a brief moment. According to the [[IGN]] review, "it's clear that the developers have played ''[[Splinter Cell]]'' and ''[[Metal Gear Solid]]'' games, but they haven't learned how to make it all that interesting."<ref name="ign">{{cite web |url=http://uk.xbox.ign.com/articles/606/606095p2.html |title=IGN review of ''Stolen'' on the Xbox}}</ref> The [[GameSpot]] review mentioned the game's "''[[Prince of Persia]]''-inspired feats", however "the only difficult part about Stolen is finding the patience to actually remain hidden when it's easier to just charge through the levels."<ref name="gamespot">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/xbox/adventure/stolen/review.html |title=GameSpot review of ''Stolen''}}</ref>
== Reception ==
While ''Stolen'' received little press coverage, that which it did receive was mostly poor ([[GameRankings]] average scores of 52.89% for the PC version, 56.43% for the PS2 version, and 54.42% for the Xbox version). IGN reviewer called the game's action "incredibly uninspired", concluding that "it's a game like this that truly makes one appreciate all the other stealth games on the market."<ref name="ign" />
